titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the March, Middagh, and Sands families property records 1974.038
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Jonathan W. Montgomery
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-04-05T14:17-0400

change.item: Finding aid revised and entered into Archivists' Toolkit by Nicholas Pavlik,

did.unittitle: March, Middagh, and Sands families property records

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The March, Middagh, and Sands families were allied multigenerational families who resided in Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection includes bonds, correspondence, deeds, financial records, leases, mortgages, quit claims, and other legal documents relating to property held by the March, Middagh, and Sands families of Brooklyn. Most items originated with the estate of Aert Middagh (d. 1777) and then passed to the Sands and March families by descent or marriage. Some records refer to property in Jefferson County, N.Y. Also included are land records of members of the Hicks, Luquer, and Van Nostrand families, among others, and an 1838 report of commissioners appointed by the Kings County Board of Supervisors to inquire into the loaning of $79,000 received from U.S. revenue.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); March, Middagh, and Sands families property records, 1974.038, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related archival collections at the Brooklyn Historical Society:

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids note
otherfindaid.p: An earlier version of this finding aid, containing a detailed item and folder listing, is also available. A PDF of the inventory can be found on Brooklyn Historical Society's catablog, Emma. A paper copy is also kept with the collection. Please consult library staff for more information.
